title: Texas Governor Says State Will Build a Wall Along Border
summary: Republican Greg Abbott cites President Biden's rescinding of funding for Trump wall; Latino group to challenge legality of state effort. AUSTIN, Texas-The state will begin efforts to build its own wall along its border with Mexico, Texas Gov. Greg Abbott announced Wednesday, saying the state was prompted to take action since President Biden has pulled back on former President Donald Trump's border wall plans.

title: Derek Chauvin Prosecutors Reject Allegations of Juror Misconduct in Trial
summary: Minnesota prosecutors also say they and the judge behaved properly during the trial of former police officer convicted of murdering George Floyd. Minnesota prosecutors rejected defense allegations of juror and prosecutorial misconduct and judicial errors in the trial of former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin, who was convicted in April of murdering George Floyd.

title: Microsoft Names CEO Satya Nadella Board Chairman
summary: Nadella took over as chief executive in 2014, turning the software giant into America's second largest company by value. Microsoft Corp. Chief Executive Satya Nadella will also assume the role of company chairman, the company said Wednesday.

title: CIA Names David Marlowe to Run Espionage Operations
summary: Will oversee undercover officers who recruit foreign spies, from foreign government officials to members of terrorist networks. WASHINGTON-In his first major personnel move, CIA Director William Burns has tapped a 30-year agency veteran to run espionage operations at a time when the spy agency is increasing its focus on China and retooling human intelligence gathering in an age of growing digital surveillance.

title: Attorney General Reverses Trump Policies Narrowing Asylum Terms
summary: Attorney general vacates decisions in two cases involving domestic and gang violence for applicants. WASHINGTON-U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland on Wednesday overturned two cases decided by the Trump administration Justice Department that made immigrants fleeing domestic or gang violence in their home countries generally ineligible for asylum in the U.S.

title: Ohio House Votes to Expel Former Speaker Larry Householder
summary: Householder faces corruption probe over nuclear-energy package. The Ohio House of Representatives on Wednesday voted to expel former speaker Larry Householder, who is facing charges that he and others took $60 million in bribes to prop up a failing utility.

title: Behind Confidence on Inflation, Some Anxiety Creeps In
summary: Central bank is warily watching whether the public's expectations of inflation are starting to head up. The Federal Reserve is sticking to its story. The factors that drove annual core inflation up to a near-30-year high of 3.8% in May are largely "transitory," it said Wednesday.

title: Biden's Tests for Putin, and Vice Versa
summary: He'll have to respond if the Russian crosses the President's red lines.. The test of any summit between a U.S. President and an adversarial head of state is what the adversary concludes about the American. The three hours of talks Wednesday between President Biden and Russia's Vladimir Putin seem to have involved a frank and polite discussion of strategic differences between the two nations. Now we'll find out if Moscow sees more opportunities to push and probe, or whether the U.S. delegation showed commitment and resolve that deters further Russian revisionism.

title: No Inflation Worries at the Fed
summary: Powell says there's no reason to tighten despite a booming economy.. Let's try one of those multiple choice questions we all hated on SAT tests. Question: Which of the following doesn't fit with the others?

title: Royal Caribbean Postpones July Cruise After Crew Members Test Positive for Covid-19
summary: Delay shows that positive cases on board could disrupt restart plans. Royal Caribbean Group is postponing a voyage in July after eight crew members tested positive for Covid-19, demonstrating the challenges that arise with restarting cruises during the pandemic.

title: The California and Texas Greenouts
summary: Renewables show again that they aren't reliable to power the grid.. Electric grid operators in Texas and California are again urging residents to conserve power amid a sweltering heat wave to avoid blackouts. Keeping your thermostat at 78 degrees during the summer may be the green new normal.

title: An Antitrust Bait and Switch
summary: Biden pulls a fast one to install Lina Khan as chair of the FTC.. The Senate on Tuesday voted 69-28 to confirm progressive Columbia University law professor Lina Khan as a Federal Trade Commissioner. But some Republicans who voted for her may have regrets after President Biden broke political norms and quickly named her as the new chair.

title: Mexico City Subway Collapse Report Inquiry Highlights Construction Flaws
summary: Shoddy work, unfinished welding, lack of bolts contributed to deadly incident, report says. MEXICO CITY-The collapse of an elevated section of Mexico City's subway last month that killed 26 people and left dozens more injured was caused by "structural flaws" in its construction, according to a preliminary inquiry by an independent firm released Wednesday.

title: Brazil's Central Bank Raises Rates Again
summary: Selic benchmark up to 4.25%; more increases are likely, bank indicates, citing inflation. Brazil's central bank, the first among major economies to raise interest rates since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, increased them again on Wednesday, as rising inflation and a slow pace of vaccinations threaten economic recovery.

title: ProPublica's Plan for a Poorer America
summary: A federal wealth tax would only make it harder for people with big dreams to make them a reality.. ProPublica's "blockbuster" story showing that the wealthy "pay income taxes that are only a tiny fraction of the hundreds of millions, if not billions, their fortunes grow each year," looks at first like a stunning revelation. But the whole tempest plops into a teapot once you ask yourself: How much of the total growth in the value of my home, retirement funds and business did I pay federal income taxes on last year? The answer is none. Nobody pays federal wealth taxes in America, but ProPublica and its Democratic allies are using stolen tax returns to try to change that.

title: Media Partisanship in Plain View
summary: Journalists used to aspire to objectivity. Now they barely even bother to pretend.. The media faces a growing crisis of confidence. Only 9% of Americans told Gallup last September that they have "a great deal" and 31% "a fair amount" of "trust and confidence" in the mass media to report the news "fully, accurately and fairly." And does anyone doubt that those numbers have dropped since then?

title: If Uyghur Lives Matter, the Olympics Should Move
summary: I cheered China on in 2008. Now I know better-and my brother is in a prison camp.. I cheered China on from Wuhan in 2008, when Beijing hosted the Summer Olympics. Thirteen years later, I'm advocating for the 2022 Winter Olympics to be relocated from Beijing, and for a diplomatic boycott if that option fails. My position shifted drastically because China, a country I hoped would move in a more democratic direction, instead has reached new levels of cruelty. The government has subjected my brother, Ekpar Asat, to the torture of indefinite solitary confinement, far from home, in the notorious Aksu prison camps.

title: Joe Biden's European Vacation
summary: No wonder Macron & Co. love the president: They built the model for his welfare state.. It has been a challenge to navigate through the steady drizzle of media admiration for President Biden's love-in with the Group of Seven leaders in Europe, but one ga-ga statement, from French President Emmanuel Macron, caught my eye: "I think it's great to have a U.S. president part of the club, and very willing to cooperate."

title: 'First Steps' Review: Standing on Our Own Two Feet
summary: When our ancestors made the switch from four legs to two, they freed up their hands-but there was an evolutionary price to pay.. The list is long: How culture made us human. How language made us human. Ditto for sociability, cooperation, religion, tools, consciousness, rationality, domestication, cooking, war, predation, child care, empathy, imagination and, of course, that perennial answer, God. To these, I am delighted to add walking. Jeremy DeSilva, an associate professor of anthropology at Dartmouth, makes the case in "First Steps: How Upright Walking Made Us Human."

title: Manchin's Compromise Voting Proposal Faces Bipartisan Wariness
summary: West Virginia Democrat's proposal aims to attract GOP votes for overhaul of how U.S. handles elections. WASHINGTON-Sen. Joe Manchin (D., W.Va.) laid out what he would like to see in sweeping elections legislation, aiming to stake out a position he hopes could draw bipartisan support while including provisions each party has long opposed.

title: Justice Department Sues to Block Aon Acquisition of Willis Towers Watson
summary: Government antitrust lawsuit alleges merger of insurance brokers will suppress competition. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department on Wednesday filed an antitrust lawsuit challenging insurance broker Aon PLC's proposed $35 billion acquisition of rival Willis Towers Watson PLC, alleging the tie-up would lead to higher prices and reduced innovation for U.S. businesses, employers and unions that rely on their services.

title: Biden, Putin Discuss Prickly Issues During First Summit
summary: U.S. and Russian leaders seek to ease tensions, but Biden issues warnings over cyberattacks and jailed dissident Alexei Navalny. GENEVA-President Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin sought to ease tensions during a high-profile summit, even as the Russian leader denied involvement in cyberattacks and Mr. Biden warned of significant consequences for future cyber-aggression or harm to jailed Russian dissident Alexei Navalny.

Here is a transcript, lightly edited for clarity and length.

title: Fed Pencils In Earlier Interest-Rate Increase
summary: Most officials now expect to raise rates by the end of 2023, rather than hold them near zero. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve officials signaled they expect to raise interest rates by late 2023, sooner than they anticipated in March, as the economy recovers rapidly from the effects of the pandemic and inflation heats up.

title: Recent Retirements Throw Wrench Into Fed's Economic Recovery Plans
summary: Federal Reserve's Jerome Powell says officials don't know what future labor-force participation will look like. A surge of retirements during the pandemic is scrambling the Federal Reserve's plans for taking the U.S. economy off life support.

title: John Bolton's Memoir Is Dropped as Subject of Federal Lawsuit
summary: Biden Justice Department ends Trump-era probe into whether former national security adviser aired classified information in book critical of ex-president. summary: Sector has gained 14% this quarter, more than double the gains of the S&P 500. Investors looking to cushion their portfolios against inflation helped real-estate stocks lead the S&P 500 in recent weeks.

summary: Officials signaled they expect to raise rates by the end of 2023, sooner than they had anticipated in March. U.S. government bond yields posted their biggest one-day advance in three months on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve signaled a sooner-than-expected increase in interest rates.

summary: Trading revenue has boosted results at big U.S. banks through the Covid-19 pandemic. The Wall Street boom is petering out at U.S. banks.

summary: Easing of the pandemic, rather than a transitory rise in inflation, caused the Federal Reserve to shift its forecasts. Federal Reserve policy makers have pushed up the timeline on when they expect to start raising interest rates. That probably had more to do with the progress the U.S. has made in the fight against Covid-19 than worries about inflation.

title: Judges Need Better Security, Watchdog Says
summary: Justice Department inspector general says Marshals Service lacks capabilities, resources. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Marshals Service has neither the capabilities nor the resources to adequately protect federal judges at a time when threats against them have skyrocketed, according to a government watchdog report released Wednesday.

title: House GOP Leader Criticizes Bipartisan Bills Targeting Big Tech
summary: Kevin McCarthy says legislation would give too much power to enforcement agencies. summary: A look at Scallop Path. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

summary: Car maker to spend $35 billion on electric and autonomous vehicles through 2025. title: Why Liberals Dominate Federal Bureaucracy
summary: Republicans usually thought of an appointment as a couple of years in punching a ticket to be used later going up the corporate ladder, whereas whenever a Democrat was appointed to fill a key post, a fire was lit in the agency and the careerists were more than happy to stroke the flames.. I am a former member of Kimberley Strassel's "faceless, nameless bureaucracy," and she is right about the "liberal monopoly over federal agencies." However, she fails to tell us why this is so, why "'federal government employee' is increasingly interchangeable with 'registered Democrat'" ("The Partisan Bureaucracy," Potomac Watch, June 11). It has little to do with the list of bureaucrats leaking news stories. That's as far removed from an explanation as my reason for once leaning left: I did not enjoy having lunch alone in Washington.

title: Giving Vaccines Enables Further Dependency
summary: Without a longer-term plan for self-sufficiency, developing countries will remain dependent on wealthier countries, and the U.S. taxpayer, for vaccine donations.. "U.S. to Donate 500 Million Vaccine Doses" (U.S. News, June 10) presents a clear picture of President Biden's meek response to the global Covid-19 pandemic. He declares that America can muster only hundreds of millions of vaccine doses for a world population of over seven billion people.

title: Make It a Double (Thursday Crossword, June 17)
Another View on Diversity Of Flags at Our Embassies
summary: Just as much of an asset was our capacity for openly acknowledging our failures and shortcomings as well as our efforts to address them. Our interests are best served when we continue that tradition, and these flags are part of that.. Two retired foreign service officers, Dave Seminara ("Diplomats Abase America," op-ed, June 1) and David F. Rogus (Letters, June 9), attack recent instructions from the State Department to American embassies permitting the display of BLM and gay-pride flags. I don't know where these gentlemen served or when but I was a foreign service officer for 34 years, including two assignments as ambassador. My overseas service was in Africa and Western Europe between 1970 and 2004. Over the course of that time I found that the very idea of America was a tremendous asset to our diplomacy. By that I mean the success of our political system, our economic success, our capacity for innovation and the attraction of our culture. Just as much of an asset was our capacity for openly acknowledging our failures and shortcomings as well as our efforts to address them. No American was more admired than Martin Luther King Jr. Our interests are best served when we continue that tradition, and these flags are part of that.

title: Many Potential Workers Have Moved On and Moved
summary: I know of quite a few people who moved away from cities during the pandemic and so are no longer part of the potential workforce there.. Regarding your editorial "A Good Worker Is Hard to Find" (June 5): It isn't only incentives that make workers hard to find. I know of quite a few people who moved away from cities during the pandemic and are no longer part of the potential workforce there. Most of them found a new, less expensive, more comfortable and less-pressured lifestyle that enabled them to spend time with their children, and are now choosing to stay home and raise them rather than rush to the rat race and stick their children in child care. Some people actually like being around their children and not depending on teachers to be their babysitters.

title: These Are the Dates You Should Be Stocking in Your Kitchen
summary: This versatile fruit delivers concentrated flavor and complex sweetness to desserts, savory dishes, smoothies, salads and so much more. Here's where to get the good ones.. WHY DID the fig ask the raisin out? Because he couldn't get a date.

title: Heat Wave in West Brings Record High Temperatures
summary: Salt Lake City and Tucson are among cities sweating through all-time highs above 100 degrees. summary: Fraudulent tags are being used in drive-by shootings, fine and toll evasion, officials say. The New York Police Department will crack down on counterfeit temporary license plates, officials said Wednesday, noting that the fakes have proliferated during the Covid-19 pandemic and have been tied to vehicles involved in drive-by shootings, crashes and toll evasions.

title: An Olympian, a Failed Drug Test and an Accused Burrito
summary: Runner Shelby Houlihan on Monday said a contaminated pork burrito caused a false positive. Her lawyer now acknowledges even she isn't sure what she ate.. Shelby Houlihan, one of the United States' top middle-distance runners, caused a stir this week by announcing she had received a four-year doping ban after a failed drug test that she said was caused by tainted pork in a burrito.

title: Personal Observatories Help Homeowners Aim for the Stars
summary: Resume Subscription. Humans have long been fascinated by celestial objects, but with the telescope's invention in the early 1600s, people could finally see them more clearly than they ever had before. In the centuries since, telescopes have only gotten better and human fascination with space persists. Today, anyone can have a telescope, but die-hard space fans have observatories at home.

title: Morgan Stanley Hires Greg Weinberger Away From Credit Suisse
summary: The investment banker's departure comes as the Swiss bank deals with losses tied to the meltdown of Archegos Capital Management. title: Double-Height Ceilings Changed the Game for These Tall Chicago Homeowners
summary: Stephen Harriott and Yuleika Saume built a spacious concrete home with an open first floor and ample outdoor space to accommodate their 6-foot-tall teens. Chicago couple Stephen Harriott and Yuleika Saume have a big family-heightwise-and the prospect of two ever-taller teenage boys inspired their move to a capacious new family home on the city's North Side.

title: The High Costs of a Tax Hike on Dividends
summary: Biden wants to soak the rich, but the middle class will notice when firms return less to shareholders.. The Biden administration has released a flurry of tax proposals, including a headline-grabbing tax hike on capital gains that would apply retroactively from April. Dividends would be subject to the same treatment, according to a recently released Treasury Department document.

title: Untraceable Bitcoin Is a Myth
summary: How could the FBI recover $2.3 million of the pipeline ransom? It isn't a mystery.. How did the Justice Department recover $2.3 million of the ransom paid by Colonial Pipeline to a group of hackers known as DarkSide? Isn't bitcoin, the cryptocurrency in which the payment was made, supposed to be untraceable? Actually, no. Bitcoin is anonymous, but it's far from private-an important but often overlooked distinction. The Justice Department recovered more than $1 billion in bitcoin in various investigations during 2020 alone.

title: A New Biden Product Line
summary: Paintings by the president's son may surpass those of George W. Bush.. Add another title to the résumé of Hunter Biden, son of the U.S. president. Previously known primarily for his well-paid adventures in Ukrainian natural gas, Chinese finance, Romanian real estate, and Russian-backed computer manufacturing, the dashing man of letters is now taking the art world by storm. Turns out that Hunter Biden is also a painter, and as in so many of his other notable ventures, he seems to have discovered a well-heeled and enthusiastic clientele. Is there anything Hunter Biden can't do?

summary: Four stylish women disclose their swimwear non-negotiables-like cuts that make them feel confident in their bodies-and the reliable suits they return to summer after summer. Twelve months later, once-Instagrammable suits are languishing at the back of your dresser drawer: scrunched up, regretted, never to lounge atop a tippy pool float again.

title: 'Morningside Heights' Review: Enduring Love
summary: A mind's unexpected diminishment grounds a poignant, illuminating portrait of a marriage.. Can a novel feel too familiar and too close to home to offer the sort of novelty and enlightenment that we seek in fiction? I wondered about this when I picked up "Morningside Heights," which takes place practically in my backyard on Manhattan's Upper West Side, is peopled by characters I might run into in Riverside Park, and concerns an incurable disease whose ravages I am all too familiar with from my mother's long slide into it.

title: Can Interior Design Help Beat the Heat? This House Does It Right
summary: As the mercury rises, consider these decorating tricks-also ideal for summer retreats as well as suburban and city digs. title: Meet the New Chinese Economy, Same as the Old Chinese Economy
summary: China's recovery from the pandemic relies on the same drivers of growth that powered the country before the pandemic, with the same underlying risks. Firing up the old industrial model helped the country return to 2019 levels of output while the global economy was still depressed, but it also shows off long-festering fragilities.

title: Apple Struggles in Push to Make Health Its Greatest Legacy
summary: Tech giant has envisioned hiring doctors to offer primary care, now focused on Watch. Apple Inc. Chief Executive Tim Cook has said the company's greatest contribution to mankind will be in health. So far, some Apple initiatives aimed at broadly disrupting the healthcare sector have struggled to gain traction, according to people familiar with them and documents reviewed by The Wall Street Journal.

title: Kim Jong Un Says North Korea Faces Food Crisis Due to Flooding
summary: 'The agricultural sector failed to fulfill its grain production plan,' Kim says. SEOUL-Kim Jong Un said his country's food situation is getting tense, an acknowledgment of the continuing challenges inside North Korea following a year of major flood damage, pandemic shutdowns and ongoing sanctions.

title: China to Release Metal Reserves in Effort to Tame Commodities Rally
summary: Releasing reserves of copper, aluminum and zinc may reduce price pressures on manufacturers. China said it would begin to sell major industrial metals from state stockpiles, an effort to squelch factory-gate price increases that have hit a 13-year high and are stoking fears of global inflation.

title: China's Economic Growth Moderates as Consumers Stay Cautious
summary: Investment and domestic consumption fell short of expectations in May despite a boost from a long holiday. BEIJING-China's economic growth moderated in May as flattering comparisons to the pandemic-hit economic figures early last year tapered off and Chinese consumers continued to keep a close eye on their pocketbooks.

title: The Best Books to Read in Summer 2021
summary: Authors Marlon James and Brit Bennett, model Kaia Gerber and others talk about memorable new novels they've read and why you'll love them. Book lovers shaking last year's sand from their beach bags are eager to restock with the latest page-turners. To help them, The Wall Street Journal asked a dozen prominent readers, writers and book-world insiders what works of fiction excite them this season. Here are their suggestions, some published in the spring, many coming this summer:

title: In Jamaica, a '90s Hotel With Timeless Appeal
summary: The antithesis of a gated resort, Jakes has always drawn locals to its relaxed restaurants and bars, while the accommodations-increasingly luxurious-still capture the singular experience of being in Jamaica. For the Time Capsule series, we spotlight a cherished restaurant, hotel or landmark that's changed remarkably little over the years. This week, we visit Jakes in Jamaica.

title: Big Companies Boost Share of Black and Latino Directors
summary: S&P 500 companies took substantial steps to diversify boards this year. Still, majority of directors remain white men.. The biggest U.S. companies sharply increased the number of new Black and Latino directors named to their boards this spring, a step toward diversifying boardrooms, a new study found.

title: Education Department Forgives $500 Million in Debt for Former ITT Tech Students
summary: Biden administration taps 'borrower defense' allowance to expand debt relief. The Education Department has approved another $500 million in loan-forgiveness requests from former ITT Technical Institute students who say they were swindled by the now-defunct chain of schools, as the Biden administration expands its use of debt-relief programs.

title: Israeli Airstrikes Hit Gaza as Nationalist March Stokes Tensions
summary: A surge of violence poses an early test for Israel's new government; limited air attacks apparently cause no deaths or injuries. JERUSALEM-Israeli police fired rubber bullets at Palestinians trying to disrupt a right-wing nationalist march in Jerusalem, while Hamas militants launched incendiary balloons into Israel that triggered Israeli airstrikes in the Gaza Strip, raising the specter of renewed violence in the region.

title: Not Being Amazon Is a Selling Point for These E-Commerce Players
summary: Resume Subscription. BROOKLYN, N.Y.-On a Wednesday afternoon earlier this year, workers at an industrial center raced back and forth grabbing items such as paper towels, children's toys, and liquor, then sorted them into packages destined for customers expecting delivery just hours after placing their orders.

title: Mortgage Companies Are Making Money Off Your Forbearance Plan
summary: Rocket, Wells Fargo and others are buying loans in forbearance out of government-backed bonds, then selling them back to investors. When homeowners paused mortgage payments early in the Covid-19 pandemic, their mortgage companies found a way to make a buck.

title: Iran Election Underdog Contends With Hard-Liner, Voter Apathy
summary: Friday's pivotal presidential poll could strengthen the clerical establishment if Abdolnaser Hemmati stumbles. TEHRAN-As Iranians prepare to head to the polls on Friday, the only way for the leading moderate candidate to make any headway against the hard-line presidential front-runner is to convince millions of Iranians to bother voting at all.

title: Chinese Trucking Startup Seeks to Raise Up to $1.6 Billion in U.S. IPO
summary: Full Truck Alliance targets maximum valuation of roughly $21 billion. Full Truck Alliance Co., a Chinese startup that provides an Uber-like service for the road-haulage industry, aims to raise as much as $1.57 billion from its U.S. initial public offering, a filing showed.

title: Regeneron's Antibody Drug Cuts Risk of Death in Some Covid-19 Patients
summary: Trial results for REGEN-COV buoy hopes that doctors could soon have a new way to tackle severe hospital cases. An antibody treatment developed by Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc. has been shown to significantly cut the risk of death among certain hospitalized Covid-19 patients, raising hopes for a valuable new tool for tackling severe cases.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Alibaba Falls Victim in Large Data Leak
summary: Software developer scrapes 1.1 billion pieces of user data, including IDs and phone numbers, over eight months. A Chinese software developer trawled Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. 's popular Taobao shopping website for eight months, clandestinely collecting more than 1.1 billion pieces of user information before Alibaba noticed the scraping, a Chinese court verdict said.

title: Peru Faces Turmoil After Divisive Presidential Vote Is Disputed
summary: Left-wing candidate's narrow lead is challenged by rival Keiko Fujimori, who has won backing from some retired military commanders. LIMA, Peru-Nine days after a divisive presidential election, Latin America's once-admired economic star, Peru, is grappling with political upheaval as the trailing candidate insists the vote was stolen and her establishment supporters are demanding a new election.

title: FDA Authorizes More Covid-19 Vaccine Doses From Troubled Plant
summary: The agency cleared 15 million J&J doses, bringing the total doses authorized for export to 25 million. The Food and Drug Administration cleared an additional batch of Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine doses Tuesday from a troubled production plant in Baltimore.

title: Southern Baptist Convention Elects Ed Litton President
summary: Alabama pastor favored by many young and nonwhite Southern Baptists defeats Georgia pastor Mike Stone in runoff. Alabama pastor Ed Litton was elected the next president of the Southern Baptist Convention on Tuesday, a victory for the more moderate forces within the country's largest evangelical Christian denomination.

title: Weinstein's Extradition to California Is Approved
summary: The imprisoned former Hollywood producer could be transferred to Los Angeles by mid-July. A New York judge ruled Tuesday that Harvey Weinstein can be extradited to Los Angeles, paving the way for the former Hollywood producer to face sex-crimes charges in California after more than a year of delays because of the pandemic and his health.

title: Trump White House Pressed Justice Department on Election Claims in Emails
summary: A House committee released communications showing efforts to enlist the DOJ in bolstering false claims the November election had been rigged. WASHINGTON-The House Oversight Committee released email exchanges on Tuesday that shed new light on the Trump White House's unsuccessful efforts to get the Justice Department to investigate baseless claims of voter fraud in the weeks before President Biden's inauguration.

title: Lumber Prices Are Falling Fast, Turning Hoarders Into Sellers
summary: Prices have dropped from record highs, spurred by the economic reopening and potentially pointing to an eventual return to normalcy. Lumber prices are falling back to Earth.

title: Silicon Valley Friends Charged in Insider-Trading Ring
summary: Six face criminal and civil charges over trading in shares of Infinera and Fortinet. Authorities on Tuesday charged a group of six friends in Silicon Valley with insider trading, alleging they shared unlawful stock tips and traded on the information to earn about $1.7 million.

title: Lina Khan, Critic of Large Tech Firms, to Lead Federal Trade Commission
summary: Biden designates her as FTC chairwoman following Senate confirmation as commissioner, signaling tougher antitrust enforcement ahead. WASHINGTON-The Senate on Tuesday confirmed Lina Khan for a seat on the Federal Trade Commission, and President Biden tapped her to lead the agency, a post that will allow her to pursue aggressive enforcement of U.S. antitrust and consumer-protection laws.
